Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Oracles are pretty fast, what can be slow is if there is lots of Oracle tx in a single block. My streamer didn't use oracles. Just the raw data in op return

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: txid lookup is what takes the time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then iterating backwards using the txid vin as linked list

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: total number of oracles wont matter, the nunber of simultaneous access would

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
Hmm can't publish 63999 bytes data (https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/H3b4FZ3sff/) to D type oracle.
Getting an error ```datasize 64001 is too big
{'result': 'error', 'error': 'datasize 64001 is too big'}```

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Shouldn't it fit 65536 bytes?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
Took all the latest oracles changes when tested my app:
```git log -1
commit 76d120fa72e307112423cff793077ec6be16d38b (HEAD -> FSM, origin/FSM)
Merge: b1dc77875 8089c2a86
Author: jl777 <jl777@users.noreply.github.com>

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: https://github.com/jl777/komodo/blob/master/src/cc/oracles.cpp#L799 I wonder this check may be a reason

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when i said max size was 10000 for OPRETURN, that meant that 10000 is the most that will fit in an opreturn

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes that prevents making horrible oversized things

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just because it is 16 bits doesnt mean you can max out the bits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: using that logic, any 64 bit param would mean you can use (1<<64) -1

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: I see

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
8 KB file published to D ðŸ‘Œ 
Will split data on 8 KB chunks so

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
If I'm ensuring the sequence with which `oraclesdata` transactions getting to mempool is it enough to be sure that  `oraclesdata` sequence in oracle will be in same order in which I'm sending it? 
Making kinda protocol for broadcast - not sure if data chunk number encoding in data overkill or not ðŸ¤”  For now monitoring mempool seems to be enough - but maybe there is some other factors might happen in production - like a mempools synchronisation over the nodes

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: 800 KB file succesfully published in one block :3040_kingpeepo: (actually 2 blocks needed - one on oracle creation/preparation - second on uploading itself)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it should only be able to be mined in sequence, or at least all tx in a block would be referring to other tx in a block. otherwise it would be invalid input

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: with my experiance .. if your making a heap of txns that are dependant.. you need to mine them too... otherwise they dont propagate the mempoool

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Out of order packets in (VoIP/video) network terminology is called jitter.  That kind of software uses a jitter buffer to reassemble/reorder packets into correct order.   Just an fyi

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
@Alright
txfee for oraclescreate
txfee for oraclesregister
txfee for oraclessubscribe/s (+ topup on sum of chunks * datafee on this change) 
txfee + datafee for each oraclesdata

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: using just the OP_RETURN like I did in the streamer make 10% more space. Thats putting a txd and a int32 at the start for identificatino purpousess....if using an oracle isnt much mroe than that, oracle is better as you can locate it inothe chain faster.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: different use case

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: but yea

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: i believe ya

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oracles put less data as overhead

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: by 10% more I mean if you make a chain with only a file in it... the raw blockchain is 10% bigger in total... not sure how a raw op_return can be bigger than an oracle?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oracle uses vin for indexing

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: so oracle has whole op_return used aswell?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, it does add some txids, so adds 64 bytes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but compared to 8kb it is small percentage

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: streamer was only 1 txid ... so liekly they are much the same.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: streamer has no index though.... hard to find files in current state

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
The format of oraclessubscribe is: `oraclessubscribe oracletxid publisher amount`

1)The amount can be anything greater than datafee correct? 
2)Say datafee is 10 COINS and the amount 1000 COINS is used to subscribe, the publisher will be able to publish 100 times. Is it correct?
3) What happens if the amount used to subscribe is 1001 COINS, I mean 1 COIN will be leftover, If the same pubkey does oraclessubscribe with 9 COINS, will the publisher able to publish once?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless bugs, it should work that way

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: @gcharang Yes, Only for 3) I would have to check...

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
Thanks, one more question:
If the datafee is 10 COINS as above, but pubkeyA subscribes with 1 COIN and pubkeyB subscribes with 9 COINS. will the publisher be able to publish then?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, funds are paid to the publisher pubkey CC address

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I found this mistake in the `oraclesdata` method today and I don't know what information is missing:

Look for the `===`

```
Data is submitted using the hexstr property. The first portion of the hexstr property must include ===; this sets the string length for the rest of the data. The second portion of the hexstr property is the data itself.
```

Can anyone here please tell me what the first part of the hexstr property should include?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
Its in this section: https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/cryptoconditions/cc-oracles.html#oraclesdata
afaik it should be the `data type`

lets wait for @Alright or @TonyL to answer this @Bryan_Beus
